caption: A really lovely and interesting museum, especially as it's free to visit, I would definitely recommend. The staff were friendly on the entrance, but there was one woman in the house that seemed a bit grumpy and wasn't rude with us, but was a bit rude with a few other visitors for no apparent reason. The artwork and exhibition was really well laid out and in a beautiful area though. There was a café on site which has a few bits if needed, and plenty of seating. Toilets are also available.

Gorgeous museum in the 9th. One of my favorites during my visits and it’s free also! Beautiful interiors and great displays of artworks around. Staffs were nice as well. Highly recommend you visit this small but stunning place.
Free museum in a small old house. The art isn’t great, but it’s interesting.  Admission is free. Admission to the current exhibition was €10 and was a collection of paintings of horses.
A beautiful hidden cafe garden + a little gallery! Strongly recommend to visit !

An amazing place to visit. It's a small museum, but with a great amount of art pieces. You can find paintings (including Delacroix), hand writing of famous personalities (such as Chopin), furniture and other itens. Easy acces through metro, with a beautiful garden and qualified staff. Best of all: it's free!

ROSE: It’s free, quiet (on a quiet street) and gorgeous and there’s a garden and a café where you can chill later. The staff, including security at the gate, is incredibly chill and lovely. The guy in the café has the kindest heart! There’s a very small gift shop. You are allowed to keep your backpack if you wear it on the front or hold it in your hand.  THORN: The lack of accessibility and translations. It’s very small and can get pretty crowded. I was there on a Wednesday… yes… children. The café closes super early.  BUD: Hourly guided tours! Or maybe a couple of times a day. One of them in English… Or a pre recorded audio tour… because I had questions!
Very unique atmosphere there, taking into the account that the main exposition is free: 5 stars.

The great thing about visiting Paris not for the first time, but in my case the 3rd time is that you get to go to these little charming museums at small mansions (just search “musée” on google maps! The city is littered in them)which in some ways are more enjoyable than the big important museums you see during your first time. This one has a small but charming collection of the art and personal effects of George Sand, the novelist. The garden beside the museum is very enjoyable as well - within the old (maybe original?) greenhouse that is a cottage core fantasy, you will find a small bar where you can order wine, coffee and some bottled drinks. What a nice peaceful way to spend a couple of hours.

I went there in May 2023 during Françoise Pétrovitch’s exposition, it was quite interesting to see the way the artist included her colorful modern art pieces in this old house amongst the older paintings and furniture. I loved the contrast.  As to the permanent expositions, highly recommend visiting anytime (maybe not during the Olympics because it might be too crowed). I loved seeing some of George Sand’s property pieces and paintings done by her relatives. I also did not know she drew on top of writing (pretty cool). I also liked Ary Scheffer’s paintings (but George Sand has my undying love because of Fadette).

Very beautiful museum. The entrance is free. It was a pleasure to see George Sand collection. Unfortunately I couldn’t find a place in the café. If you want to enjoy the cafe I recommend you to go there in the morning.
It’s free and interesting, so five stars. I do with it had English signage. There was a nice concert the day we visited.

Very busy on a Saturday afternoon and it’s a small space so overcrowded. I think they should limit the amount of power pole entering at a time. The woman at the entrance was rude but also perhaps overworked, they needed another person at the entrance to control access to the museum and the temporary exhibition. Entry is free to the museum, it’s a pretty house but not big. There is a cafe outside. Stairs with no elevator due to it being an old house.

This is one of the free museums you can visit in the heart of the Montmartre area of Paris. This museum doesn't have a lot of things, you can complete the museum in 45 mins, and all the information is displayed in french only. There is a beautiful tea garden cafe inside it where you have coffee and some snacks.
Not a big museum but very lovely - they also don’t always have temporary expos so it is pretty small - but nonetheless, a great museum.
Very quiet and beautiful, it’s seems that you are in another city! A very good place to take a break from the city chaos. Also very nice Café inside! (and it’s completely free!)

A lovely little free museum with some very interesting pieces from people like George Sand and Frederic Chopin. There’s even plaster casts of their hands!  Unfortunately it is VERY hot inside as there’s obviously no air con, so unless you’re particularly hardy in the summer your visit will probably have to be quick. Outside is a cute cafe and garden, and next door is a secondary area with a paid ticketed exhibition.  A good place to visit if you’re already in the area or if you particularly love the theme.

Free museum, cute little nuggets of culture in Paris. Works of famous  authors, painters and writers can be found here. Worth seeing and walking around the area if you’re in Paris for long or you’ve been to Paris many times but haven’t been to less touristy areas.

This residence is located in the district “New Athens” Invited artist Francoise Pétrovich is showing 40 pieces, drawings, inks on paper and oil on canvas created specially for the museum. You can see it until September 12 th.
Very nice museum in Paris where you can spend an hour, then chill in the coffee shop and enjoy the garden.

Small tucked away museum in the city. free entrance with a little cafe on the side.  The Musée de la Vie Romantique is located in the house of the painter Ary Scheffer, built in 1830.  Situated in Pigalle, in the Nouvelle Athènes district, the museum recreates a harmonious historical setting evoking the romantic period. The ground floor is devoted to George Sand and includes portraits, furniture, and jewellery from the 18th and 19th centuries. On the first floor, contemporary works are exhibited around the paintings of Ary Scheffer.  An exhibition, and concerts, readings and activities for children are programmed. In the garden of the museum, the tearoom Rose Bakery is a delightfully tranquil spot and serves delicious snacks.

Situated in a nice quiet neighborhood, this house has a lot of history as it used to shelter the famous romantic author George Sand and it is one of the three literary museums in Paris. Ary Scheffer used to live here too, his studio was here where he used to welcome his guests and where the artistic activity was in full swing in the 19th century in Paris. You can now admire different family possessions and nice paintings and sculptures made by their contemporaries. The museum is quite small, it takes less than an hour to fully visit it. The view in the windows is beautiful, as they open to the yard that is full of plants. There is also a tea house in the garden which has a nice vibe totally in line with the name of the museum. The entrance for the permanent collection is free.

Musée de la Vie Romantique or Museum of the Romantic Life is dedicated to the literary/cultural movement of Romanticism. A movement that gave absolute credibility to the author or painter's own emotions to create an experience through his art.  Entrance to the permanent exhibition is free.  The museum was formerly the main residence and studio of Ary Scheffer - a Dutch-French painter. There are two main buildings on the property, one the house and one the artist's studio.  Ary Scheffer was known to host intellectuals and artists of his time at his home. And this is what makes the museum special. You get to imagine a fragment of how it might have played out with artists and authors mingling, music being played, recitals. The list of the visitors to the house is impressive - George Sand (who was his neighbour), Ernest Renan (his niece's husband) Frederic Chopin, Eugene Delacroix, Franz Liszt, Gioacchino Rossini, Pauline Viardot and Charles Dickens! The museum has a little bit from a few of them. The main personalities focused are George Sand, Ernest Renan and ofcourse Ary Scheffer himself.  His studio also houses two breathtaking sculptures including one of Ammani Ammal, an Indian dancer, sculpted by Jean Auguste Barre!  The reason for one star less is that I would have loved to see more of the other visiting artists or maybe drawings of them together at the house to better weave their story. Also the stairs need some maintenance.

A sweet little museum tucked away in a corner, it mainly displays works by the French painter Ary Scheffer. This place used to be the painter's house, and the museum has done a great job in retaining its likeliness.
This is like a private small house. The cafe here is comfortable. To just enjoy the atomosphere here is OK.

A very small space in a lovely old atmospheric house. Often crowded. Interesting collection from estate of renown Romantic writer George Sand.  Sculpted hands, and jewelry, tchotchkes. Unusual drawings by Delacroix. Did Van Gogh see these? !9th century paintings — portraits mostly — by Ary Scheffer, Ary Renan, marble head of Christ sorrowing by Auguste Clesinger, relief by Pradier (?), exquisite by the writer. herself and more.  Often quality contemporary exhibitions that you pay for. Beware: Only ONE toilet! A terrace cafe nicely tendered by trees.
I found the interior somewhat dull- however - it’s free, on a quiet street, pretty on the outside, and the cafe is quaint. But don’t feel bad if you can’t make it

Not sure was I was expecting - I saw it was close to my stop and decided to check it out (it's free too!) One thing I did like that made it different from other museums is that you see things that make you realise that oh these were real people who lived here - there's a lot of quite fashionable accessories and a lot of sketches of people done by the occupants. It's a small museum but very thought-provoking
Beautiful little museum a hidden area but beautiful

This place os romantic as it gets! It really feels like you’re walking into a secret garden. There’s a beautiful home/museum with paintings inside, and outside is transformed into a cafe area where you can sip your coffee and eat some baked goodies. There’s also inside seating too, but it gets warm really quick. The cafe doubles up as a green house that’s inside the cafe, hence the warm temperature. This is a great place for a small break and take pics

The entrance is free for the permanent collection which is quite small but lovely. Sometimes they hold a temporary exhibition too. The café and the garden are really cute but super packed on the weekends.
Cute small museum in Paris. Was a historical meeting place for French intellectuals and musicians. Has a garden/cafe area.
A small free museum with a beautiful garden.  After visiting the museum you can stop at the garden to drink coffee and admire the flowers.

The popular spot for Instagrammers 💕💕💕💕 We made it there finally 😍😍😍 Me and my husband have visited this museum in December and we absolutely loved it ❤️❤️❤️ Make sure you add this to your Paris itinerary 💕💕💕🌍🌍🌍

Nice small museum! There aren't too many exhibition rooms, but the story is very interesting and the collection feels complete. For the English speakers between you, all of the descriptions are written in French, but if you use Google translate you are good. The buildings and the back yard are beautiful, especially on a nice day. There's also a small cafe on the back.

The highlight of the museum is the magnificent cafe in a green garden, ideal for a refreshment in the summer. The museum itself is not something special but rather interesting and of course it is free. Its worth a visit.
Little museum with interesting history. Don’t miss the little lunch-tea room in the courtyard. The courtyard gives you the feeling of being far away in the middle of busy Paris.

A quiet, peaceful place to visit. If you don't speak French it's worth reading up on it before you go as there are no English translations or English speaking guides. Its quite a small place so didn't take long to look around.
Nice and free museum. Very small
